The Prime Minister welcomed Admiral Sir andrew cunningham to the War Cabinet and stated that his appointment as First Sea Lord and Chief of Naval Staff would be announced thefollowing day. The Prime Minister added that it would be necessaryfor Admiral Cunningham to return to the Mediterranean for a fewdays before taking up his new appointment.Naval, Militaryand air operations.(previous reference:W.M. (43) 132ndConclusions,Minute 1.)Air Operations.Home Theatre.Mediterranean.2. The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of theprevious six days.Bomber Command had carried out four major attacks againstBochum, Hagen, Munich and Kassel. During September bomber command had dropped 14,860 tons of bombs. United states aircraft had dropped 7,000 tons during the same period, of which1,100 tons had been on Germany. Coastal Command had made fiveattacks on U-boats. During the six days we had lost 42 bombers,16 aircraft of Fighter Command and the Tactical Air Force and2 of Coastal Command. Enemy losses had been 32 aircraft destroyed, 2 probably destroyed and 12 damaged.United States aircraft had dropped 900 tons of bombs onEmden.Allied Air Forces had attacked targets in support of the land battle.United States Air Forces had bombed targets at Munich,Augsburg and Vienna. 65W.M. 134 (43VPacific.naval operations.Shipping Losses.Home Waters.Indian Ocean.MilitaryOperations.Pacific.Russia.Kos.In recent air fighting at Wewak and in the Solomons 93Japanese aircraft had been claimed as destroyed as against the lossof 3 Allied aircraft.Shipping losses by enemy action for the previous six days,including belated reports, amounted to 22,800 tons. Confirmedshipping losses by enemy action for the month of Septemberamounted to 105,000 tons.Our light forces had been active in the Channel during theprevious week and 1 enemy trawler had been blown up and2 destroyers'damaged. One merchant ship had also been torpedoed.German and Japanese U-boats had torpedoed 3 merchant ships in the Indian Ocean.A detachment had been landed at Termoli and, having repulseda number of counter-attacks, had now joined up with the8th Army. Indications were that the Germans were preparing aline on the River Volturno.Corsica had been almost completely evacuated by the Germans.Finschafen was now cleared of Japanese.The main Russian advances had been in the north in the areaof Vitebsk and Gomel. Further south the Russians had gained a footing on the west bank of the Dnieper at two points north andsouth of Kiev. Only a small portion of the Kuban Peninsula nowremained in German hands.The War Cabinet were informed that on the previous morning7 or 8 enemy transports, together with landing craft and coveredby 2 destroyers, had landed a force on the Island of Kos. Thelatest reports, which were from German sources, indicated that thetown of Kos was in German hands together with some 200 prisoners.The remainder of our forces were stated to have retired to the hills.Details were given of the disposition of our naval forces in theMediterranean, and reasons for the smallness of our force in theKos area.The War Cabinet were informed of the counter-measurescontemplated.The War Cabinet-Took note of these statements.Italy.Future of the.Italian Fleet.(previous reference :W.M. (43) 132ndConclusions,Minute 4.)3. Some discussion took place about the disposal of the italian fleet, and in particular of the Littorio Class Battleships. It wasnot clear that any of the instruments so far signed gave the united nations the right to dispose of these ships, and it was important that this point should be fully safeguarded.The War Cabinet-Authorised the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs,after consultation with the First Lord of the Admiralty,' to arrange for a paragraph to be inserted in theCunningham-Courtin agreement to the effect that theUnited Nations have the right to dispose as they, thought fit of the ships of the Italian Fleet; but if the memorandumcould not be satisfactorily amended, then to arrange forthis point to be covered in the long armistice terms.Italian Prisonersof War.(previous reference:W.M. (431 128thConclusions,Minute 1.)4. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs stated that itwas clear that the time had come when the status of italian prisoners of war would have to be defined anew.The War Cabinet-Invited the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs, the Minister of Labour and national Service and the Secretary of State for War todraw up a set of conditions which could form the basis ofan agreement with the Badoglio Government on thismatter. Anglo-Soviet-AmericanConference.(previous reference:W.M. (43) 127thConclusions,Minute 6.)6. The War Cabinet' were informed that the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs would be leaving before long to take partin this. Conference.The Prime Minister said that the Conference was, in thenature of things, bound to be largely of an exploratory character,and it would not, therefore, be appropriate or necessary that weshould attempt at this stage, before we had learned the Russianviews, to crystallise our final opinions on the many issues of far-reaching importance which would have to be settled after the war.The question was raised as to the stage at which the DominionGovernments should be consulted.Mr. Bruce said that the most helpful course would be for theDominion Governments to be kept informed of the trend of thoughton major questions. An indication of the development of opinion would be of the greatest assistance to the Dominion Governments.The Prime Minister agreed with this view, and said that theDominion Governments would be kept informed of the course ofthe discussions at the Conference.Armistice Day.(previous reference:W.M. (42) 140thConclusions,Minute 5.)7. The War Cabinet-Agreed that the procedure for celebrating Armistice day should be on similar lines to that followed in 1942, and invited the Home Secretary and Minister of Home security to arrange accordingly.Offices of the War Cabinet, S.W. 1,4th October, 1943.Ita*y- 5. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that he had proposed Visit received a request from Sir Walter Citrine that one or two repre-of T.U.C. sentatives of the Trades Union Congress should be granted facilitiesRepresentatives, to visit Italy. The present suggestion was that two representativesof the Trades Union Congress should pay a visit (in company with two United States colleagues) in order to study such questions asport conditions, and that they should then return to this country.General Eisenhower's permission would, of course, have to beobtained.The question was raised whether the United States members,of the party would be chosen from the American Federation ofLabour. On this, the view taken by the War Cabinet was that weshould consult the United States Government and should accept their decision as to how the United States representatives should be chosen.After further discussion, the War Cabinet Invited the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs in. thefirst instance to ascertain, through the American Embassy,the views of the United States Government on the proposed visit.
